title: There Must Come a Reckoning for Our Media
text: In two weeks, Americans will decide whether the United States shall continue as a representative democracy and the shining beacon on the hill of freedom and liberty, or will devolve into a corrupt autocratic state where political enemies are jailed or killed and the world’s greatest military will be deployed within our own borders to racially cleanse our nation of immigrants, both legal and otherwise. Those are stark choices. Our media systems, both corporate and independent (including this one), are committed to selling us this false equivalence between the two sides, framing the election as a close race, when in fact the chasm between the two visions for America could not be wider. The media thrives on the drama of competition, the narrative of a horse race, because it keeps readers and viewers engaged. It drives traffic, boosts advertising revenue, and sustains the endless cycle of speculation and commentary. But in doing so, they have abdicated their responsibility to the truth, and the public has been left confused and divided. Manufacturing Suspense The reality is that this election is not a battle between two equally valid political ideologies—it’s a stark confrontation between basic principles of good governance, rooted in the Constitution, and the wholesale destruction of that very foundation. Yet, the media has continuously presented it as a legitimate contest, stoking fears of a too-close-to-call outcome, and capitalizing on the anxiety of undecided voters. The endless barrage of "polls tightening" headlines, "swing states up for grabs," and exaggerated focus on fringe candidates create the illusion that both sides are playing by the same rules. This framing ignores the existential threat posed by one side's willingness to subvert democratic institutions, disenfranchise voters, and reject the results of a legitimate election. Instead of clarifying these stakes, the media’s profit-driven incentive has been to amplify the narrative of suspense, creating a psychological rollercoaster for the electorate. False Equivalencies and Clickbait Democracy At the heart of this issue is the false equivalency the media clings to, out of either fear of backlash or in pursuit of clicks. In a normal political landscape, such neutrality may be understandable, but this is no ordinary moment in history. When one party endorses election-denying candidates, conspiracy theories, and political violence, treating both sides as if they are equally legitimate undermines the very democracy the media claims to serve. The click-driven model of journalism has poisoned our discourse, reducing nuanced debates about policy and governance to shallow arguments about personality and optics. Election coverage is less about what candidates will actually do if elected, and more about the spectacle of who "won" the latest debate or who has momentum in the polls. This superficial reporting not only distorts the reality of the stakes but also demoralizes voters who see their legitimate concerns about democracy reduced to ratings fodder. The Cost of Distraction The most dangerous outcome of this media-driven narrative is that it distracts from the real and urgent threats to the nation’s future. Instead of focusing on policies that undermine the rule of law or dismantle civil rights, we are treated to endless punditry about electoral strategies and the latest gaffe. This election is not a contest of personalities or political preferences—it's a referendum on whether the Constitution and the principles of democracy will endure. But by treating it as just another election, the media has allowed dangerous ideas to creep into the mainstream without consequence. Even now, the media plays a pivotal role in legitimizing those who reject the basic tenets of democracy. By giving airtime to extremists, presenting misinformation without fact-checking, and failing to hold those who lie accountable, they’ve emboldened the very forces that seek to tear down our democratic institutions. This election should not be framed as a "choice" between two different versions of America—it’s a fight for the continued existence of a free, democratic state versus its total collapse. A Reckoning Must Come The media cannot escape its culpability in the erosion of democratic norms. There must come a reckoning for those who have failed to stand up for the truth, who have chosen profit over principle, and who have treated this moment of existential threat as merely another news cycle. Journalism is supposed to serve the public, to inform and educate, not to entertain and exploit. In fact, while the media sells the story of a close, nail-biting election, the reality on the ground tells a far different story. Polling stations are seeing record turnout, early voting numbers are shattering expectations, and the enthusiasm gap between those who seek to preserve democracy and those who support its destruction is stark. Far from being an evenly split electorate, a majority of Americans clearly understand the gravity of this election and are voting accordingly. Numerous independent polls and data sources show overwhelming support for candidates who stand for democratic governance and reject autocracy. In battleground states and districts, early voting numbers and registration surges indicate that a large portion of the electorate has already decided, and they are voting in droves for stability, equality, and constitutional governance. The media's portrayal of a "close race" is not only misleading—it is dangerous in that it masks the real momentum on the ground. There is a palpable sense that this election may, in fact, be a landslide for those defending the rule of law, and the media’s focus on "tightening polls" and "undecided voters" is a disservice to the public. The media is also ignoring its own reporting: The surge in young voter registrations, especially among young black and Latina voters; the number of registered Republicans who will vote for Harris in protest of what Trump has done to their party; the number of vets and those who respect our military who are disgusted with Trump’s disrespect, and to top all that, this will be the first presidential election since the Dobbs decision, and every other election so far since that horrific destruction of human rights in America has been a “surprise” to the media who’s polls woefully undercounted democratic support. This election is not going to be close. Harris/Walz are going to win in a landslide. The media will act surprised, as if no one could have seen it coming, except for all of us telling them its coming. This isn’t just speculation; it’s supported by hard data. States like Georgia, Arizona, and Michigan—once considered swing states—are seeing unprecedented early voting numbers that favor democratic candidates by wide margins. While corporate media may choose to downplay this, independent analysts have pointed out that the enthusiasm for maintaining democracy is overwhelmingly strong. From massive grassroots organizing efforts to voter mobilization campaigns, Americans are recognizing the stakes, and it’s becoming clear that this election is less of a "toss-up" and more of a blue tsunami. The media’s failure to cover these realities creates a dangerous false narrative. Instead of reporting on this extraordinary wave of civic engagement, they choose to focus on sensationalist headlines that drive fear and uncertainty. This is no accident—it feeds their profit machine. But the outcome of this election may very well reveal a different story: One where the majority of Americans decisively reject extremism and reaffirm their commitment to democracy. The stakes are not just the outcome of an election—they are the survival of our republic. The media must be held accountable for the role it is playing today, and we as citizens must demand better. Without a functioning press committed to the truth, democracy cannot survive. It's time for a reckoning.
